utterances.utterance: Well, I'm not so sure these are going to be extremes. Maybe in a general election, some would be branded as such. But he's really kind of coming to where the Democratic Party has been for a long time. Again, Congress is a lagging...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Well, it wasn't his party.

utterances.speaker: RUBIN
utterances.utterance: Well, Congress...

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: He had been an elected official for over 40 years. If you don't know your political philosophy by then...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: But people evolve. People evolve. Have you evolved on that stuff?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Evolve, or you cave because of political pressure.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: For 48 hours, you changed your position. RUBIN: Well, hold on. I do want to push back on this, because we should commend our elected officials when they change their mind in light of new information. I think that's...

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Did he change his faith? Because he said...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Before he was running for president, he wasn't changing those views.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Yes. You have to take a look at the timing a little bit, right? I mean, if he had just come out and said, hey, I changed my mind while I'm hanging out by the pool...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: But to be fair, Kat, he wouldn't be the first candidate to do that.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: No, it's what politicians do.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: But is it going to hurt him? I guess what I'm asking you is, he's considered the most electable. He has the biggest lead ,although that is beginning to change in some states. Elizabeth Warren is soaring and all. I'm just wondering, what's your take on his so-called invincibility?

utterances.speaker: RUBIN
utterances.utterance: Sure. So I think the people who were upset about Joe Biden not supporting -- or - - excuse me -- who was supporting the Hyde Amendment, he's not going to win those voters over now that he is against it.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: RUBIN
utterances.utterance: With that said, I don't think he's going to lose any voters because he is now against it.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: What about the president's comments, sleepy Joe and all that stuff?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Well, I believe that the president -- and Joe I think is smart for making this a general election type of race and not a primary race. But there's going to be some accountability for his past policy positions.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: You don't think that comes back to hurt him? Hillary Clinton was acting that way, and she ignored...

utterances.speaker: RUBIN
utterances.utterance: Accountability for what? This president...

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: The crime bill.

utterances.speaker: RUBIN
utterances.utterance: Where's the accountability on this president, who is still separating families?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: But we're not talking about that right now. I don't like the whataboutism. We're talking about Joe Biden specifically.

utterances.speaker: RUBIN
utterances.utterance: Oh, of course.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: You still think he's going to end up the nominee?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: ... accountable for the crime bill. I agree with Lawrence.

utterances.speaker: RUBIN
utterances.utterance: I think right now Joe Biden is the favorite to win the nomination, but, again, there are candidates behind him that are surging. The debates are going to be interesting.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Why won't he go on the airwaves? Why is this campaign insulating him? They don't want him to go out.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: He is a gaffe machine.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Like or hate the president, but at least he will speak for himself. He doesn't hide behind the advisers.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Or tweet. Or tweet.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: And he will tweet.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: All right, guys, I wish we had more time. Blessedly, we do not.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: All right, in the meantime, more developments in the Dominican Republic situation, and now the FBI is involved and lots of others too -- after this.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: She could be the seventh victim. A Staten Island woman's death in the Dominican Republic is now being questioned. FOX News' Steve Harrigan in Santo Domingo with the very latest. Hey, Steve.

utterances.speaker: STEVE HARRIGAN, CORRESPONDENT
utterances.utterance: Neil, the seventh victim of this mysterious ailment that is killing American tourists here in the Dominican Republic is 53-year-old Leyla Cox from the Dominican Republic. She came here to celebrate her birthday on Sunday. Instead, Monday morning, she was found dead in the resort. Authorities here are calling it a heart attack. We spoke with her son earlier today. He is baffled as to how a healthy 53-year-old woman, his mother, is suddenly dead from a heart attack. He's suspicious. He doesn't believe it. He says he's being pressured to form -- to carry out a cremation. He doesn't want to do that. He's having a hard time getting the body back or even understanding what exactly happened. Here's Will Cox.

utterances.speaker: WILL COX, SON OF LEYLA COX
utterances.utterance: They have done an autopsy. They haven't sent it to me. They sent me a police report. That was in Spanish, that I cannot read. I still don't know the exact details of my mother's death, and that's where I'm hitting a roadblock.

utterances.speaker: HARRIGAN
utterances.utterance: Cox is now one of seven U.S. tourists to die in the Dominican Republic for unexplained reasons over the past several months. In the meantime, police here have now detained nine suspects in the shooting of former Red Sox great David Ortiz. They have rounded up nine, but they still have a manhunt on for several more suspects, including Luis Rivas, known as the Surgeon. He is also suspected of carrying out violent crimes in the United States. Ortiz, in the meantime, continues his recovery in Boston -- Neil, back to you.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Thank you, Steve, Steve Harrigan. Meanwhile, a grocery store is trying to shame people from using plastic bags. Well, forget the shaming. Should they just start banning? Gen Hexed is next.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: All right, the young and restless. And they're young and restless over this. There is a recent survey from Zillow, the real estate folks, that shows 14 million millennials are now living with their parents, still living with them. That works out to about one in five of them. Is this just about living expenses? Something else going on? "Your World" audio technician and author of "Blood in the Streets" Dion Baia with me. We have attorneys -- two attorneys -- I got to be super careful here -- Madison Gesiotto and Natalie Elisha Gold. You know, what's interesting about it, Madison, is that those numbers over the last couple of years have been growing, in fact, at a pretty strong pace. What's going on.

utterances.speaker: MADISON GESIOTTO, CONSERVATIVE COMMENTATOR
utterances.utterance: Right. And I think what's so interesting about that is that we're seeing the economy booming, but yet we're seeing these numbers growing. So I don't think it's strictly economical anymore, because for a while we saw these numbers, and they were starting to grow. And we said, oh, well, it's a terrible economy. And so people can't afford -- afford to go out and live on their own.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Maybe they just like their parents.

utterances.speaker: GESIOTTO
utterances.utterance: I don't know about that. Let's not get carried away. I love my parents, but I bought a home.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: NATALIE ELISHA GOLD, ATTORNEY
utterances.utterance: I think it's twofold. It's really the student loan crisis, which has compounded. And now it's more acceptable to live at home until you get your second or third degree.

utterances.speaker: DION BAIA, FOX NEWS
utterances.utterance: Well, this was generations ago.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Is that right, second or third degree? This is why we have a college debt problem.

utterances.speaker: ELISHA GOLD
utterances.utterance: That's the big problem.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: Generations ago, this was a regular thing. You would move in.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Generations still live in the same house.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: Now you're going -- a lot of people of this age are going paycheck to paycheck, and then with the student loans, you are coming out of college $100,000, $150,000 in debt.

utterances.speaker: GESIOTTO
utterances.utterance: And incredible interest rates on those, 6, 7 percent for many folks.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: And if you live in a city like this, where it's very -- it's very high cost of living, it gets pretty tough.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: You're in your mother's basement.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: I am in my mother's basement, not my dad's.

utterances.speaker: ELISHA GOLD
utterances.utterance: And the big problem is that, if we don't fix this problem, there's going to be blood in the streets, to your book.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Elizabeth Warren has a plan. Maybe she will help you out. All right, I also want to follow up something else that's catching our attention. There is a grocery store in Canada that aims to shame customers into not using plastic bags by handing them out with embarrassing phrases on them like wart ointment and some things I can't repeat because this is a family show. But, reportedly, people still wanted the bags. What I find odd about this, guys, is that I think that's obnoxious on the part of the grocery store.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: They're handing them out for free. And then they're trying to guilting you to take one. And then it's become like a collector's thing, where people are going in just to get these particular bags. And if you're -- my grandmother's going in there, and she's getting an adult video store bag, it's just -- it's kind of embarrassing twofold.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: As if that's new in your...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: What do you think? Is it -- I know, paper, plastic, whatever. But if someone is trying to shame me into making a choice that I made?

utterances.speaker: GESIOTTO
utterances.utterance: Yes. Well, first of all, it totally backfired on them, because we have so many people going in there now to get the bags because they think it's funny. But for me and many other people, I think if we see that they're doing this, I'm just going to the next store. I'm not going in there. I travel a lot. I can't take a reusable bag with me everywhere.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: But, of course, what if it's already filled with stuff?

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: You just turn it inside out first.

utterances.speaker: ELISHA GOLD
